Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Greg uses astronomy as a background to teach people to think outside the box. This class focuses closely on solving Fermi Questions (back of the envelope estimations) which is helpful for anyone who wants to consider a consulting job (exactly like market sizing questions). It also teaches some basic astronomy concepts (seasons, tides, lunar phases) which are just fun to know.

I learned about how the sun, the moon and the earth work. I learned a lot about different features of space. I also learned to assess things like our energy usage, global warming and how long the earth will last.
How to think about huge numbers and hard-to-grasp concepts. How to make estimates, how to ponder life, how to see numbers in things that seem un-calculate-able.
Order of magnitude estimations and critical reading of scientific news are the main benefits of the class.
I learned a lot about how to do order-of-magnitude calculations. I also learned basic astronomy concepts such as the phases of the moon, how orbits work, and the structure of stars.

My primary take away from this course was learning how to do order of magnitude problems which consist of trying to answer an impossible question like "how many sand grains are there on Earth" with a numerical answer. Other than that I can say that I learned more of the concepts associated with astronomy, like the phases of the moon and the formation of the sun. I couldn't tell you much about how these concepts are applied specifically but I think they were generally covered well.

I learned about Earth in its cosmic context, literally. I learned so much about our planet and the universe, from things related to astronomy to things completely unrelated (e.g. stocks?!). I learned to also go with my gut and intuition (something that so many of us are trained to not do), which sometimes does lead you to a close answer. This is a course that really forces to explain yourself (especially in estimation problems), which is always a good skill to work on.
Order of estimation calculations are the main skill you will learn from this course.
Learned estimation skills, very interesting phenomena in space, critical thinking.
I learned what a bit coin was and how to estimate the number of trees in Connecticut.

I learned how to approach order of magnitude estimation problems, and I learned the phases of the moon!! I also learned about other stuff (climate change, hurricanes, etc) and, more importantly, I practiced talking about scientific concepts and problems in practical ways, and I practiced having to tale and then defend a position on those issues.

I learned how to properly estimate different quantities and how the phases of the moon and seasons work. I learned about relative distances and values that concern the Earth, giving me a better understanding of the Earth in its cosmic context.
I somewhat developed the ability to better estimate numbers based only on the loose knowledge I have.
I learned to be more critical and reasoned in my thinking.

Order of magnitude estimation skills and a bunch of seemingly random but very cool information. Also, a deeper understanding of the role of science in our world, better intuition for discerning between scientific sources, and more generally, science literacy skills.
I learned basic astronomy and order of magnitude evaluations
This class is mostly about critical thinking. I got way better at estimation and reading scientific literature.
An interesting class, definitely kind of out there in terms of topic, but I loved the professor and thought it was fun.
I learned how to make back-of-the-envelope estimations to solve interesting questions about the Earth.  I also learned basic astronomy principles and about some of Earth's most basic processes.

ability to make estimations
now know a bit about the moon
I developed a better sense of the physical attributes of the world and the universe.
Critical thinking, order-of-magnitude type questions, thinking about things that are seemingly impossible in a sensible and approachable way.
Order of Magnitude, basic knowledge of astronomy.

Very few. It was a times interesting and the professor is a good lecturer, but I learned very little concrete science. It was much more a perpetual thought experiment and a lot of order of magnitude estimates. Nothing else.

Regarding skills, this course taught me how to go about Order of Magnitude estimation and demonstrated the relevancy of scientific thinking in everyday judgment. As for knowledge, we touched on several topics, some only tangentially related to Astronomy, such as: energy and entropy, computation, the fundamental definition(s) of life, the Earth system and global warming, the potential for life on other planets and moons, interplanetary travel, the lifetime and interior processes of the Sun, the age and formation of the Earth, the seasons and phases of the Moon, circular acceleration and orbits, and gravity. Ultimately, the study of Astronomy, even on an introductory level, tends to be a humbling experience, reminding us of our cosmic smallness; throughout the course, Professor Laughlin posed some deep questions (in homeworks and in lecture) that certainly developed my perspective.

This course helped me become more comfortable dealing with unfamiliar information and complex concepts. Throughout the course, I was challenged to learn new material quickly and apply it in a new, creative way.
ORDER OF MAGNITUDE ESTIMATION. CRITICAL THINKING. ORGANIZED THOUGHT PROCESS
Whole lotta critical thinking skills

The order of magnitude estimation skills allowed me to leave this class with the ability to calculate anything I could possibly want, with little or no starting information. From rocket science to solving world hunger, you leave this class knowing you are capable of solving anything.
I learned how to think about problems using an order of magnitude approach.
None. Greg's a nice guy, but don't take this class, I did not learn anything besides how to draw a diagram of the phases of the moon. You can learn more topical things.
Estimation and reasoning skills
how to estimate
Estimation skills.
How to use certain skills to apply to scientific concepts and phenomena, such as the phases of the moon, conservation of energy, and order of magnitude reasoning.
A varying degree of information from the phases of the moon to the shifting of the tides.
I have a very basic understanding of how to problem solve using order of magnitude, and an amateur understanding of how the seasons work, how tides work, lunar phases, and planets orbits.
Skills regarding order of magnitude problems, physics, and different universal concepts.
i learned how to estimate and how to comprehend numbers in ways relevant to astronomy
I practiced critical thinking and estimations. I feel more confident with these kinds of problems now.
This class teaches an interesting method of estimation, but that is sort of it honestly.
I developed a more detailed understanding of earth, the moon, solar system, and the universe. More so, I learned some of the basics for life on earth as well as estimation skills.

Strengths: Generally an interesting class, pretty low workload (5 psets, a midterm, a final), Greg really cares about this class although the class might not echo his enthusiasm, the TAs are great (Malena and Imad both specifically)
Weaknesses: The class can be very disjointed at times. I particularly felt this after midterm. Everything was kind of just all over the place and I had trouble tying together what the big picture was. Also, there seems to be a disconnect between what we learn sometimes and what we are tested on the exam... for example, we spent 5 minutes on tides in class, yet on the practice exam a full question was dedicated to an extremely specific and applied an instance of the tides?

Strengths: Professor Laughlin is an engaging professor who has a good grasp on how much work students are willing to put into a class that they are taking only to fulfill a requirement. The class is relatively interesting for a science credit.

Weaknesses: The problem sets are ridiculous. Estimating what cousin the centipede is to me was a complete waste of time. I did not learn anything new from questions like these, and I could have spent the time actually learning something in the senior seminars I am taking.

Greg has a tendency to ramble, but he's still super interesting. Slides are almost all pictures, which is fine, but if you miss class they won't help you--BUT Greg uploads notes which are amazingly helpful since it can be easy to lose track of where discussion went.
It is an entertaining and relevant course. The workload is very manageable. The lectures can feel a little long at times.

This course was honestly a bit all over the place. This is not necessarily a bad thing, but I think it's something students should be aware of going in. We learned about what felt like a completely different set of topics every week, and even at the end it is hard to find a cohesive thread throughout it all (besides the ever-present order of magnitude estimations). The problem sets were often shockingly difficult and time-intensive, even though the lectures rarely explored topics that were hard to grasp. Sections were not mandatory, but I think they should be - it would have been impossible to complete the problem sets without them. I always went to section to get help with the problem sets, and even though I would do my best sometimes I could just not come up with exactly what the professor was looking for. This became increasingly frustrating throughout the semester.

The lectures were kind of all over the place, Prof. Laughlin would skip around a lot. The homework was manageable, but the TFs were not very helpful. The course could use a little bit more structure in terms of the material covered.

I love the applicability of the course material, as well as the structure of the course. Professor Laughlin makes such effortless transitions between topics that sometimes you can't even tell you transitioned from one topic to another. This strength, however, is also a weakness: sometimes, I would sit in lecture not knowing what exactly I was supposed to learn at that moment.

Strengths: You will 100% learn order of estimation skills, which is integral for consulting / general problem solving. You'll learn to be really comfortable with working out reasonable answers to ridiculous questions like how many air particles are there in a room.
Weaknesses: Greg isn't a super engaging lecturer
Strengths: very insightful, very engaging, very relevant. Professor Laughlin is an excellent lecturer.

Prof Laughlin is a really funny and likeable professor, and he makes certain topics interesting. I think he puts a lot of effort into making assignments fun, such as that time we watched a cliff-diving video to a dubstep remix. However, the class doesnt really focus on space, and you may learn a LOT about estimation and some non-space things like bitflipping (but Prof Laughlin relates it back to Earth in its Cosmic Context somehow)

The lectures were interesting but sometimes went off topic, which was fun and engaging. The psets were somewhat difficult unless I went to section or office hours, which as an athlete was very difficult because of my practice hours.

Professor Laughlin is funny and engaging, but the course trajectory is not clear. There were a lot of scattered topics that never really came together, and the homework is significantly more difficult than what's covered in class. They also graded pretty harshly and didn't provide clear feedback on how to improve, since a lot of it is guess work and estimation that you have to somehow get a feel for. The homework definitely needs to be completely re-written for the next semester it's taught and the TAs should be more understanding about people's different levels of experience; there were several times where I went into section with prepared questions and left even more confused than I was before.

Weakness: It is not very intuitive to many and the lectures seem very disconnected. It is very hard to study for this course, and for some problem sets, the only way to get a good grade on them was to go to office hours.

The course is extremely random. We learned everything from the interior structure of the sun to how DNA works, and it was very difficult to follow week to week. The course should focus more specifically on topics of astronomy.

The strength is definitely lecture itself. While you could probably miss and still do fine on PSETS/exams, Prof. Laughlin was hilarious and had very interesting things to say every single time.

Weakness was probably the PSETS. They asked questions that were sort of related to the main content of lectures and exams but not really. They were sometimes needlessly tedious and grading across the board was very inconsistent. Despite this being an order of magnitude class, points would be docked for putting a number like 3 rather than a fraction. For a class that emphasizes strategic thinking over getting the right answer, this was incredibly frustrating. I greatly appreciate the practice exams because those felt like the questions that should have been on our homework. They involved rigorous thinking of concepts we learned in class rather than calculating human cousinship with centipedes. It was in doing these problems that actually helped me internalize the material.
It felt like a hodgepodge of facts about the universe and solar system that didn't really tie back to anything major
Gregory Laughlin is simply delightful. Its weakness is that it's extremely broad, but its strength is that Laughlin makes everything exciting and interesting.

Sometimes, class felt a little disjointed and random. It was kind of unclear exactly what we were supposed to take away from each class. I wish Prof. Laughlin started each class stating what he hoped for us to learn by the end of the class, or in some way gave us some thematic continuity.

I thought the course was really great.  One thing I thought was really great was how much we learned about basic Earth processes like the phases of the moon, seasons, etc.  I did not think that there were many weaknesses in the course.  While it would have been nice if grades had been put in quicker and some course information had been communicated more clearly, but it did not take away from my enjoyment of the class.

strengths - entertaining, estimation was useful
weakness - structure, no idea what I actually needed to know

Strengths - Dr. Laughlin posts everything so even if you didn't get anything from lecture he has your back.
Potential weakness - Course content for the most part is not directly relevant to the midterms.

Strength: the professor is really patient and really cares about teaching
Weakness: course moves slowly, not suitable for those who want to learn a lot of astronomy.

Strengths: some interesting material, very little memorization, good professor
Weaknesses: pointless information, more math than what a non-QR credit should be, little direction

This course's greatest strengths were the vast scope of content we covered and Professor Laughlin's enthusiasm for presenting those ideas. The course may be improved by streamlining the lectures from the first half of the semester, as I felt that we could have progressed through the basic concepts more quickly and without the cool but often confusing tangents.

Professor Laughlin is hilarious and does his best to make the lectures exciting and stimulating, despite a lack of class participation. You receive clear feedback on your problem sets and there were lots of opportunities to ask questions in office hours with the prof or with the TAs.

Although the class really trains you to think creatively and critically even when you're given very little information, the class could use a little more organization. It was often difficult to draw macroscopic connections between different sections of the syllabus.

I always enjoyed attending lectures and found them to be engaging and interesting. Sections were a bit less exciting, as they were mostly used as a way to help with homework. This help was definitely useful, but I would've liked to learn some of the material in more depth.

I loved Professor Laughlin's lecturing and sense of humor. The topics covered in class (especially in second semester) were incredibly fascinating.

Some problem sets felt a lil too challenging. I also felt that I received too little feedback. If I got something wrong on the problem set, the class wasn't really structured to help me ever understand what I did wrong.
I liked the way the course made us think.

Pick something and focus on that thing, rather than doing a smattering of topics at a very surface level. Either explain the physics or remove it. Homeworks are often totally unrelated to the material; they should be changed or eliminated.

Strengths- engaging instructor, interesting ideas 

Weaknesses- confusing lectures, felt very long
good prof
Professor was very engaging.

This course covers a lot of ground, and in this way goes over a lot of interesting concepts but is at times a little confusing and hard to orient yourself in the material. I did however, learn new ways to approach scientific problems which is helpful.
Strengths: Professor Laughlin was very engaging and the TFs were very accommodating. Section was extremely helpful
The lecture sometimes just felt too long, or it felt unrelated to the content that seemed to be important for homeworks and exams.
It was hard to figure out what we needed to know and what we didnt need to know which made it hard to follow along at times.
the course is good overall however lectures could be more related to test material
The material can be really interesting and is, usually, presented in a clear and very interesting way with enthusiasm. The lectures could be a little shorter.
More organization, faster grading, better feedback, more connection b/w lecture and psets are necessary.

The course covers a wide range of topics and challenges our thought processes to use the estimation methods. Lectures are super interesting and the use of videos and texts helps. At times, however, the lectures were a bit all over the place.

If youre looking for an easy Sc credit, I would take this class. The weekly psets are challenging but mostly based on creative thinking/estimation and the TFs in section are really helpful. Professor Laughlin is charismatic and a very reasonable prof

Yes, but only if you know what you're getting into. It's not a QR but you should definitely, DEFINITELY be comfortable manipulating numbers and thinking about them on a large scale, otherwise you will definitely struggle.

If you need to fulfill a science credit and are not willing to put in a lot of work / are not very interested in science, this is a great class to take. Otherwise, most of the lectures are boring and not worth your time.

A great SC credit. A good deal of math, but nothing specialized. Great for students who enjoy science but also like critical thinking. Psets are weird and confusing but fun. Lectures feel like fireside chats. I hate to admit that I even enjoyed the midterm.
All who are interested in a non-intensive science credit (particularly those in humanities) would enjoy this class.

I would recommend this to non-science majors looking for a science credit. However, I would warn prospective students that even though it may seem like a gut for the first few weeks, it is not (or, at least, it will not feel like a gut when you are spending hours doing and redoing a single question on a pset). It is an enjoyable class, and I have gained reasoning and scientific analysis skills that I don't think I could have picked up in any other Yale course. However, if you want to take this class you need to be willing to actually go to section and ask for help, because it is impossible to complete the work otherwise.
I would recommend this course as a gut SC credit for someone in the humanities and no one else. You might learn a little about astronomy and will probably do okay if you try a little bit.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student! This is a wonderful, low-stress science credit, and even if you don't need a science credit, you probably will want to take this course too. You get to learn fascinating things about the universe (and yourself) that you'll remember even after taking the final exam.

Honestly, if you're looking for a gut that requires you to just memorize stuff and be done with it, look somewhere else. I came into this thinking that it would be a gut, and it definitely is an easy science credit, but if you're looking to coast and chill, this is not the class for you. One of the PSETs involved going up to a high point in New Haven and sketching out the four cardinal directions.
This is an excellent course. Professor Laughlin is a great lecturer and explains concepts and goes through mathematical processes clearly.
I would recommend if you need a SC and have a basic understanding of math! Not the most engaging class, but definitely interesting tidbits of information that you could learn.

Okay, here's the thing--I think Professor Laughlin is amazing and better than I deserve and, unfortunately I was also a senior taking this class for a science credit. I don't know that I would recommend this class to others in my position. The material is pretty interesting, Prof. Laughlin is hilarious and brilliant, and he is really, really doing his best to make students like me learn something that will be of some actual use. This made my total apathy all the more devastating. This class is not that difficult but it will ask you to spend some time genuinely thinking, so...you decide if you are up to that challenge or if you want to take a science that is more based on memorization, which this is not.

Yes, I really learned a lot about how the Earth fits into the universe and how to answer seemingly huge estimation questions, which could be useful in the future since places like Google use hiring questions similar to those.

I would not. I really enjoyed Professor Laughlin's teaching style, but this class, which was supposed to be an engaging science credit for non-STEM people, ended up causing me unnecessary stress and anxiety this semester, likely also due to the fact that in order to get science credit, I had to take it for a grade. We get assessed based primarily on some truly arbitrary homework questions, one midterm, and one final, and the harsh grading meant that a lot of people in the class are going to get bad grades not due to their inability to understand science, but rather because the course material wasn't organized to help us learn and improve.

Professor Laughlin is very engaging, but the subjects were way too varied. We learned everything from the interior structure of the sun to how DNA works, and it was very hard to follow any trends week to week. That said, topics are generally interesting and the homework is very manageable (only five problem sets throughout the semester).
Yes, it's good for an easy science credit

Yeah! Take it if you need a science credit and want an overview of many topics. This class is called "Earth in Its Cosmic Context," which means anything on, in, or around Earth is fair game. You might as well call this class "Science Class." As an English major in need of my last science credit, it was the perfect thing to take to make sure I don't forget the basics before I go out into the world. You also get better at estimating and practical math. Laughlin is so nice, and you only really have to do the psets (you don't actually have to do the reading or go to section, don't worry).

Yes! Definitely, if you need a science credit. It's not too difficult but the order-of-magnitude estimations he really wants you to learn are such a good skill in life. I think the questions he asks can definitely be a little bit crazy, but if you entertain them, then its really interesting to think about! He is an amazing, funny, caring professor. He will remind you of Bill Nye the science guy.

Yes, I would! This class is definitely not super easy, but the workload is pretty low and the course material is interesting.  Also, Professor Laughlin is amazing! He is hands down the best part of this class. Go to office hours!
yes if they are interested in astronomy and learning how to do order of magnitude estimation, no if not

If you are decent at math and have a good sense of order-of-magnitude questions, you will do fine in this course. This course is basically all about order-of-magnitude and knowing random facts, so if you into that the course is good!
No. I found this course to be very boring and the material covered did not satiate my curiosity for the cosmos.
Recommend to those who want a science credit with not that sciency class. Not recommend to those people who are good at STEM.

Very slow on the grading which made it hard to know how you were doing in the class. And when we did receive feedback, the point system seemed arbitrary and not fair. My peers and I collaborated on our problem sets (as we were encouraged to do) and received vastly different scores. Otherwise, a good science credit. Our universe is amazing.
Perfect for an SC requirement, requires limited math and is based on critical thinking.
Nope

NO! 
I would hope that my fellow classmates were honest enough in their evaluations, but based on past evals, I see that I can only trust myself to do for YOU what students of previous semesters failed to do for ME. In the event that you have found this buried in a pool of yeses, I must convince you to take my word over those of my well-meaning yet naive peers. I can only imagine that this would be the case because the multitude of students that would have told you the same probably declined to answer every question on the course evaluation.

So, let me give you all a realistic take on this class. First, if you actually want to learn Astronomy, do not take this class. If you're comfortable with math and science or have a strong STEM background, do not take this class. If you're weak in STEM and are looking for an easy science class, DO NOT take this class. By now, I imagine you're picking up what I'm putting down. This class is about estimation, not astronomy. That much is made clear from the get-go, but it isn't until after the midterm that the gravity of your mistake in taking this course dons on you. The actual work is easy enough on paper, but there's an underlying vagueness to everything that never really disappears. While you will scratch the surface of some astronomical concepts, the ultimate end and gimmick is for you to be able to tackle questions like "how much water is there on earth" or "for how long can Connecticut supply the United States' food needs" without any given information. Instead, you must rely on "outside-of-the-box" thinking to get close enough approximations. All questions are worked out using units of grams, cm, and ergs, and all numbers and constants are rounded to 1, 3, or 10 of some order of magnitude thereof. If you're already scratching your head, I understand. Other evals will no doubt advise that this takes some getting used to and that while at times unfocused or too simplistic, there are some interesting insights to be gleaned from Professor Laughlin's lectures, but the sad truth of the matter is that this class is just annoying.

I'm sure there will be those who read this evaluation and, for whatever reason, refuse to heed the warnings. Theirs is a callow idealism and, unfortunately, I cannot save them. But I may yet save you, well-meaning but savvy reader. You're likely combing through course evals in search of a low-stress, fairly easy course that may or may not also fulfill your SC requirement. Whether said course material is interesting is probably a secondary consideration (though the answer here is still "no"). So save yourself the headache and look elsewhere. Actually, I'll go ahead and save you the trouble of looking, free of charge. Take ASTR 160 in the Spring or whenever it's offered. Or take something else. Just don't take this class. You're smart enough to make smart course selections, and well...this ain't it, chief.
You should definitely take this course, especially if you need a relatively chill SC credit. You'll learn a lot, you'll have fun and the problem sets are totally manageable.
Good course if you want an easy-going but still fairly interesting science class. Don't recommend it if you actually want to be learn astronomy.
Yes, this was an interesting and challenging course that encouraged students to engage with familiar problems in a unique way.
No, the class was not very clear about expectations, with work intensity changing weekly

I would absolutely recommend this class because it is an incredibly fun way to learn really cool skills. Professor Laughlin and the TAs are invested in the class and the students. I found myself telling others about what I was learning in the class and the conversations I had with my professors because it impacted me that much.

Greg is a nice guy and I like him, but do not take this course. You will not learn anything and then you will be tested on it. A lot of the course is estimation problems, which you can and might do on your own. The course is trying to be pop science for non-science majors, but it ends up being pop science for middle schoolers. There is no central focus, no coherent narrative; if someone asks you what the course is about, you will not know what to say. The homework always has questions with no relationship to what we learned in class. The homeworks consist largely of googling things and then applying those googled concepts, which is kind of absurd, like usually in a class you're applying what you learned in that class. Don't take this as a science gut, take something else like Plants and People, or Ornithology if you're willing to do work. There's no way to know how grading works, which is also stressful.
Juan Guerra is a great TA and you should take his section if, despite my explicit warning not to, you take this class. If you take this class, by the time you get to week 4, you will say to yourself, Man, I wish I had listened to [Anonymous Course Reviewer], who absolutely warned me and who I rashly ignored.
Yes, because it was a relatively easier science credit
yes
Yes.
If you are not a science major but still enjoy science, I would recommend this course. It does use some mathematical concepts, which was tricky for me, but the assignments are pretty straightforward.
Yes, if looking to get introduced to Astronomy at a basic level.
Unless someone is extremely into physics and astronomy and science type stuff, then I would not.
yes, it is a good science credit class for people not interested in science majors
Yes, I would. Especially for non-science majors. The class tackles lots of interesting question pertaining to science, while not expecting much prior knowledge of science.
Honestly manageable science credit, more math than expected for a non QR
I would! The class is a good survey science course for non stem majors, being the perfect amount of challenging and interesting.

If you're looking for a SC credit that's well-taught, interesting, and not super hard. Prof Laughlin is great - it's clear he's excited to teach the class and puts in work into preparing lectures. The TAs this term were also very friendly and helpful. Psets were manageable and midterm/finals are not that hard to study for with a little review.
